newsitem.title: CANADA: Fletcher Canada unions set July 14 strike.
newsitem.headline: Fletcher Canada unions set July 14 strike.

text.p: Fletcher Challenge Canada Ltd said Tuesday that unionized workers at its three British Columbia pulp and paper mills have announced they will go on strike July 14.
Contract negotiations between two unions and the company broke off Tuesday. The 2,400 workers have been without a contract since April.
Officials from the Pulp, Paper and Woodworkers of Canada and the Communications, Energy and Paperworkers unions were not immediately available for comment.
But in a statement, Fletcher negotiator Howard Burleigh said the unions agreed to cooperate in an orderly shutdown of the company's mills at Crofton, Elk Falls and Mackenzie.

Union members recently voted 96 percent in favor of a strike if the contract talks failed. The unions aimed to reach a "pattern" contract at Fletcher, the province's biggest pulp and paper maker, that they would then seek to replicate at other producers.
Fletcher said the union's last demand was for a 35 percent increase in labor costs over three years including a five percent annual wage increase.

The company offered a six percent wage "adjustment" over a six-year contract, a cash settlement of C$1,000 a worker in exchange for moving to a 365-days-a-year operation and employment protection for employees affected by flexible work practices.
It accused the unions of refusing to address the company's agenda for greater flexibility and efficiency in its operations.

Fletcher, majority owned by New Zealand's Fletcher Challenge Ltd, said it "remains committed to negotiating a settlement that will support the fundamental changes required so that it may compete in a global marketplace..."
